questions.text: A 4-year-old girl who has been experiencing vaginal bleeding is brought for evaluation by her worried mother. The girl’s medical history is unremarkable, with normal physical growth and appropriate developmental landmarks. She has had all the recommended immunizations. On visual examination of the perineum, bleeding and multiple cystic masses resembling grapes are seen at the introitus.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sarcoma botryoides

Highyeild:

Sarcoma botryoides A cystic grapelike mass at the introitus. Sarcoma botryoides (also known as, rhabdomyosarcoma of the vagina) is a malignancy in infants and young children that arises from embryonal rhabdomyoblasts (ancestral muscle cells). The tumor resembles a bunch of grapes. It has a generally good prognosis with conservative surgery followed by chemotherapy. It is a rare malignant tumor of the female reproductive tract, most commonly seen in girls younger than 8 years of age. c/f: The most common symptom is abnormal vaginal bleeding .

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B & C is not possible with respect to the age of the child. Option: D. The most common cause of vaginal bleeding in a prepubertal girl is a vaginal foreign body. Ruled out by unremarkable history.

questions.text: A 65 yr old post-menopausal female came to genetic OPD with painless bloody discharge per vagina for 2 months. A PV examination was done and a mass located as given below image was noted. A sentinel biopsy was performed to look for lymphatic spread. Which lymph node will be biopsied?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superficial inguinal node The image depicts vulval cancer. Sentinal LN biopsy is done routinely for vulval cancer.

Highyeild:

Sentinel lymphnode for vulvar carcinoma is a superficial inguinal lymph node Sentinel lymph node biopsy is useful for knowing the spread of vulvar carcinoma Vulval Cancer M/C variety- Squamous cell carcinoma The most common symptom of vulval cancer - pruritis Most common sites: Labia majora and minora The most common type of spread: Lymphatics (First lymph node involved-Superficial Inguinal lymph node, and then Deep inguinal LN and femoral group of lymph nodes). For lateral tumors, only ipsilateral lymph nodes are involved whereas for midline lesions, B/L lymph nodes are involved Sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful in vulval cancer Most important prognostic factor- Lymph node status. HPV 16 and 18 are the most common risk factors for developing vulvar carcinoma: Investigations Done in Vulvar Carcinoma Physical examination Always biopsy +/–Colposcopy

Extraedge:

Lymphatic drainage of Vagina Upper 1/3rd – Hypogastric, obturator, pre sacral and external illiac Middle 1/3rd – internal illiac L Lower 1/3 and vulva- Superficial inguinal LN

questions.text: Sentinel biopsy is most effective in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vulvalca Although in both the Ca cervix and Ca vulva, the role of sentinel lymph node biopsy is not yet confirmed vulval cancer is a, better bet.

Highyeild:

The sentinel lymph node for vulvar carcinoma is a superficial inguinal lymph node The sentinel node is a specific lymph node (or node) that is the first to receive drainage from malignancy and is the primary site of nodal metastasis. In theory, the presence or absence of metastatic disease in the sentinel node should reflect the status of the nodal basin as a whole. Thus a negative sentinel lymph nod e would allow the omission of lymphadenectomy of the whole nodal basin. It is detected through perilesional injection of radiolabeled technetium-9 9 or blue dye followed by intraoperative identification of the sentinel lymph nodes. Sentinel lymph node detection has become an integral part of the management strategy for breast cancer and melanoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and D: sentinel LN biopsy is not effective. Treatment of Vulval Cancer Stage IA or invasion <1 mm Wide local excision /simple partial vulvectomy , no need for lymphadenectomy. In a simple partial vulvectomy, dissection is carried until the superficial layer of the urogenital fascia. Stage IB and II - Radical vulvectomy/Modified radical vulvectomy with thorough inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy. In modified radical/radical vulvectomy - dissection is done until the deep fascia of the urogenital diaphragm , i.e. the perineal membrane. If the lesion is central do B/L lymph node dissection otherwise if it is >2 cm from midline do ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy. Postoperative radiotherapy is to be given if 2 or more groin nodes are involved or the disease-free margin is <8 cm Stage III-. Megavoltage radiotherapy 4000-5000 rad Over a period of 5 weeks causes shrinkage. Local excision of the shrunken tumor is then adequate and eliminates the need for an exenteration operation Stage IV . It is treated by chemotherapy or radiotherapy. Anal involvement is satisfactorily treated with infusion of 5-FU and mitomycin C, followed by radiotherapy 3000 rad over 3 weeks. Local excision of the residual tumor may be required. Chemotherapy avoids exenteration operations with its associated high mortality and morbidity. Other chemotherapy agents used are as follows: Bleomycin Methotrexate Trastuzumab This regime is administered weekly for 6 weeks

questions.text: All of the following statements hold true for melanoma of vulva except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is the 2nd M/C vulval cancer

questions.correct_answer: B. M/C site is labia majora
questions.explanation:
Solution:

M/C site is labia majora The common sites are the clitoris and labia minora. It may arise from a junctional nevus.

Highyeild:

VULVAL MELANOMA Melanoma is the second most common vulval cancer. Malignant melanoma accounts for 3%-5% of all vulval tumours It occurs at all ages. Common sites are the clitoris and labia minora gross: develop in a mole or occur de novo . The lesion is pigmented and presents as either nodular or superficial spreading tumour. The edges of the lesion are often irregular and frequently ulcerate and bleed. Treatment : Radical vulvectomy and bilateral regional lymphadenectomy (en-block) is the preferred treatment. Pelvic lymphadenectomy does not alter the prognosis. Radiation therapy, adjuvant chemotherapy, or immunotherapy are ineffective. Overall prognosis is poor.

questions.text: A 20-year-old young girl presents with a history of rapidly developing hirsutism and amenorrhea with a change in voice
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Testosterone Specifically, women with an abrupt onset, typically within several months or sudden worsening of virilizing signs should prompt concern for a hormone-producing ovarian or adrenal tumor. Serum testosterone levels may be used to exclude these tumors.

Highyeild:

Masculanising Tumors Arrhenoblastoma/ Androblastoma Hilus cell Tm Adrenal cortical Tm/ Lipoid cell Tm of ovary Gynandroblastoma • Affect child bearing age group (10-35 years) It includes : Seen in postmenopausal females • Combination of granulosa cell tumour & arrheno blastoma • Sertoli Cell Tumor (SCT) Leydig cell Tumor • Characterised by presence of Reinke's crystals • Sertoli - Leydig cell Tumor • Seen in postmenopausal females • Characterised by presence of Reinke's crystals • Combination of granulosa cell tumour & arrheno blastoma Presentation: They are low grade malignancies All masculinizing tumors cause defeminization, followed by masculinization. Patient complain of: altered body contour scanty and irregular menstruation followed by amenorrhoea flattening of breast increased hair growth - hirsutism clitoromegaly receding hair line hoarseness of voice Diagnosis:Serum Testosterone levels raised>200 ng/dl and increased androstenedione. (DHEAS may be normal which helps to differentiate it from a masculinizing adrenal tumor) The most common cause of hirsutism in young girls - is PCOD (80% cases). PCOD is not associated with hoarseness and hirsutism is not rapidly developing. In PCOD - testosterone levels though raised are less than 200 ng/dl . Measuring the levels of testosterone and not DHEA because the main source of DHEA is the adrenal gland and not the ovary.
